assistance from qualified draft counselors:

The SA wants to become involved with more programs in
the school. Teachers' aids are
needed to help students with
their work. Hopkins students
could show students some of the
more interesting facets of the
sciences, social sciences, or humanities that are not normally included in a standard public
school text.
Fisher would like to start
some after school activities such
as a chess club, dramatic group,
or photography club, but he
needs advisors. Escorts are
needed for field trips.
Many of the students have
never seen a college campus or a
football or lacrosse game, and
just coming to Hopkins would be
an experience to them. Fisher
Pointed out that many of the
boys graduate Clifton Park without ever having seen lacrosse
and feel lost when they get to
high school where it is the big
Sport,
Bob O'Connor, president of the
SA, stated that there are "many
demands for imaginative programs at a school such as Clifton
Park. The opportunity, the facilities, the money, and the pupils
are there. All that is needed is
for Hopkins students to show an
Interest in the project so that
these programs can operate. We

welcome any ideas on programs
that the community can offer."
The SA will still continue its
individual tutorial program as in
past years. The group will continue to work with the Monument St. Center, Lafayette homes,
and individual requests. Other
neighborhood centers have also
asked for help.
Dr. Wickwire stated that the
experienced
program
needs
people to act as group leaders
and supervisors to help coordinate the tutoring. He stressed
that anyone interested in tutoring should attend the tutor orientation program tomorrow in Levering Hall.
Anyone interested in working
with the pupils at Clifton Park
or in individual tutoring should
contact John O'Brien, graduate
assistant to Levering Hall, at
Levering Hall.

NEWS-LETTER

Commission Reverses Key Decision
The possession of a master key
to campus buildings will no longer be considered a violation of
the Honor Code in accordance
with a recent commission decision; this reversed a previous
ruling which stated such possession to be a violation.
The immediate cause of the
original ruling was the theft of
tests by an undergraduate. The
result was severe controversy
and criticism from many facets
of the college community.
Re-examined Postion
John Sanborn, chairman of the
Honor Commission, remarked
"Pressure of the News-Letter
helped us to re-examine our position."
The original decision stated
that possession of said master
keys to Mergenthaler, Rowland,
Latrobe, Ames, Maryland or
Remsen Halls would be a violation of the Honor Code.
Holders of such keys were ad-

vised at the time to surrender
them to the proper authorities.
Chairman
stated
Sanborn
that while he "felt tradition was
being violated, the act would be
for the goad of the undergraduate body as a whole."
Nothing Violated
At that time the commission
felt that no constiutional provisions were being violated.
Sanborn stated that the commission soon realized "the constitution was grounded in tradition as well as reason."
Although the vote on the resolution was unanimous, the
members of the committee were
filled with doubt within a week.
With regard to this "paradox"
Sanborn stated, "We did it too
quickly, we didn't think enough."
In regard to the subsuquent
discovery that the act was indeed unconstitutional, he commented, "We hadn't read that
sentence of the constitution."

By last May the commission
realized the error of its ways.
Steps were taken to reverse the
ruling and Sanborn himself
spoke to several deans. This has
resulted in an agreement that
these gentlemen and not the
commission would have jurisdiction in this area.
Sanborn stated that with regard to future activities of the
commission, "this action will
cause the commission to be more
careful in the future."
Sanborn stated "that although
possession of a key is a potential academic advantage, it does
fall under the auspices of the
commission. The act must be
committed. We are not interested
in intent." It should be noted
that another such potential advantage would be in taking a
test outside the classroom.
The vote to reverse the original
unanimous decision was 19-1
with one absentee.

Speaker Sparseness
Reflecting upon the array of speakers scheduled
to appear at Hopkins this year, we find that a preponderance of scholarly figures will dominate the scene,
with remarkably few political and social critics on the
program.
The philosophy of science lecture series and the
inauguration of the symposium on literary structuralism
go far in fulfilling the University's responsibility to make
students aware of the variety of viewpoints existing elsewhere in the academic community. However, the University has a concurrent duty to stimulate interest in
the affairs and problems which characterize the real
world just beyond the cloistered halls of Homewood,
and in which students will soon have, if they do not
already, a more than academic involvement.
At present, Hopkins can look forward only to the
presentations of Secretary of Urban Affairs Robert
Weaver and Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield,
politicians who undoubtedly can do much to illuminate
domestic and international issues, but who, of themselves, are unlikely to evoke controversy on this campus.
This situation may be contrasted with the events of
two years ago, when PresideneJohnson twice descended
upon Hopkins, first during his campaign, and later in
the spring to make what has come to be known as his
"Baltimore speech".
That year also saw lectures by some of the foremost authorities on international affairs: Senators
Wayne Morse and William Fulbright, Ambassador Henry
Cabot Lodge, and then presidential advisor McGeorge
Bundy. In addition, Martin Luther King gave a moving
oration in Shrivec Hall, where Alabama's Governor
George Wallace had appeared the spring before.
In addition to the valuable insight into the issues
of Vietnam and civil rights rendered by each of these
speakers, their very presence wrought an impressive
change upon the usually sedate campus, culminating in
the demonstrations and counter-demonstrations when
Johnson and Bundy appeared.
Two years later, these issues are still very much
alive, and new ones have come along. Personnages such
as Secretary of Defense Robert MacNamara, U.N. Ambassador Arthur Goldberg, and Senator Robert Kennedy are among thsoe whose presence on campus would
generate immediate interest and controversy. Not to
limit the alternatives to the political realm, why not extend invitations to someone like Norman Mailer, or
Timothy Leary?
In its future planning, the Office of Special Events
would do well to keep in mind the importance of establishing a more balanced schedule of speakers, and the
benefits which students may derive in the form of increased personal activity in anticipation of or in the
wake of a confrontation with controversial public figures.

Round One
The Student Council is to he commended for its
forthrightness in a letter sent last week to several officials of the Administration.
Recognizing the dual concepts of freedom and responsibility as the foundation of Hopkins' philosophy
towards its students, Council president Reinseh went on
to write:
44
. • • a dichotomy has begun to develop
between the University philosophy and the reality of caniptis life ... the dichotomy lies in
w hat might be called the social realm; that is,
life at the University exclusive of studies.
And it is here that it is incumbent upon the
Student Council to point out as best it can a
trend away from the University's traditional
philosophy and toward a considerably more restrictive approach, which tends to limit the
freedom and responsibility of the student, and
places a greater burden upon the administration."
Among those examples cited by Reinsch to point
out this trend were the recent imposition of more rigid
regulations governing the freshman dormitories, and
the current rule prohibiting girls in the freshman dorms
at any time. Along with the Student Council, we urge
a reconsideration of these rules, and a general reevaluation of the entire dormitory set-up.
We hope to see initial talks taking place between
the Council and the Administration, with the possibility
of opening them to all students in the form of a panel
discussion or a forum at a later time.
We must point out that the academic freedom
which the letter applauds also appears to he facing this
name trend. The prime example here is the moving up
of the drop date. In both this instance and in the social
context above, the Administration seems to be forcing
die students to conform to the inadequacies of the University, rather than amelioratiing the inadequacies for
the benefit of the students.

Bureaucratic Tyranny
To the Editors,
Among the reasons university
education in Europe is so far superior to even "the best in
America" the local euphemism
for JHU) is that professors there
are not allowed to limit the educational opportunities of their
students by the petty and destructive use of bureaucratic tyranny, as was done at JHU in regard to the drop date.
Returning from a year's study
in Europe, I find it hardly conceivable that a professor should
voice the comments attributed
by the Newsletter (Oct. 7) to
Dean Swanson on the "abuse" of
the late drop date. Undoubtedly
I have been living in a youthful
honalee-world, for I would•have
thought that any dedicated professor would welcome any addi-

tional flexibility in the bureaucracy which would allow more
students to try his discipline.
The
American
educational
system is beset with enough obstacles to learning, without professors turning coal to the side
of educational restriction and ignorance.
Sincerely.
Michael Fischer, '67

Bookstore Discount
To the Editors,
Right from the start of this
semester the Student Council has
focused attention on different
aspects of the Hopkins Bookstore. However, in all this discussion, one essential fact seems
to have been neglected.
Faculty and Post doctoral students here at Hopkins do receive
a 10% discount on books and
supplies at the bookstore. Certainly, the purpose is to encourage these members of the community to purchase as many
books as possible in order to
pursue their various scholarly
interests. Such a discount then
lessens the financial strain on
these individuals and encourages
them to work and obtain ma-

terials through the campus bookstore. No one could argue that
this is not in the true spirit of
the university.
Why then are not students
granted such an incentive? Certainly the cost of books is high
and especially in the case of
students on partial scholarship
may be prohibitive. Which of us
has not at one time or another
hesitated from purchasing that
"recommended" book?
It is hard to imagine that the
Hopkins student is financially
more able to meet book costs
than faculty members and I
would suspect that the reverse
is true. Is it really necessary for
students to go to downtown
Washington, New York. and
other universities to find books
at a marked discount.
Hopefully the current expansion of the University bookstore
is only the first step toward more
substantial bookstore reform. A
major university like Hopkins
should certainly encourage its
students and faculty alike to buy
any and all books that will add
to their intelectual development.
James Jacobs,'69

Harriers Edge Hounds; Gridders Brace For 'Fords
Balanced Performance After Tough Loss to Bears
Leads to One-Point Win
By TOM CROCK
With a tremendous comefrom -behind performance, the
varsity crosscountry team defeated Loyola 29-30 this week.
Loyola's fine sophomore strider, Tom Carter, took individual
honors, finishing about 300 yards
ahead of the rest of the field.
Second place also went to Loyola, but Hopkins' captain, Jack
Loomis gave the team its big
lift by finishing third, 60 yards
ahead of Loyola's third man.
At this point, after taking
three of the first four places,
Loyola's coach said that his
boys had the meet wrapped up.
Hopkins' coach George Brown
simply commented, "Wait and

and so on. Loyola took first
place, second, fourth, eleventh,
and twelfth for its 30 points.
Hopkins took third, fifth, sixth,
seventh, and eighth for 29. So
even though the last two Hopkins' runners figure in the scoring they had to finish ahead of
Loyola's final two runners to win
the meet.
This is the second straight
year that Hopkins has defeated
Loyola by one point in a crosscountry meet.
The Jays next meet is scheduled for tomorrow against Haverford and Drexel on the Homewood course at 2:00 P.M.

Hopkins' harriers Cliff Cyr,
Ed Minch, Larry Hoppwood, Bob
Gayle, Paul Carlson, and Jerry
Danoff were the next six runners to finish with Danoff far
ahead of the last two Loyola
men.
A meet like this shows the
value of having a well-balanced
team. Even though Loyola had
two fine runners that finished
well ahead of the Hopkins' pack,
the Jay's overall balance was
able to counter this advantage.
The score of a cross-country
meet is determined by the position of the first five finishers of
each team. One point is awarded
for first place, two for second,

Pitch men
Open Here
With a mere eighteen men on
iihe roster, the freshman soccer
team opens its season this coining Wednesday, Oct. 19, at home
against Calvert Hall.
Even though Coach Charles
Mallonee started with twentysix men and lost his two top
prospects to injuries, he is still
optimistic for a good season.
His probable starters have plenty
of experience. He has an exceptionally good goalie, and he is
hoping to improve on last year's
2-1-2 record.
The loss of the two players on
whom Coach Mallonee based his
early plans was a harsh blow to
the potential of the beam. One
was Josh Geberer, an all-New
Jersey fullback, out with a severty sprained ankle, who hopefully
will return to the team later in
the season.
The second freshmen prospect
who was injured is Randy Miller,
a star halfback from West Hartford, Cann. He will be lost for
the entire season due to an injury.

By MIKE PHILLIPS
The varsity football team hosts
Haverford tomorrow at 2:00 p.m.
in a contest which could, as it
did last year, prove to be the
turning point of the season.
Just as they did last year, the
Jay's take an 0-1-1 record and
a lot of uncertainties into the
game. They saw the pattern of the
rest of the campaign unfold last
season when they fell 36-16 to
Haverford. Following this trendsetter were four consecutive lopsided losses.
The Fords, with seventeen
lettermen and a veteran backfield returning, should, despite,
two losses already, provide Hopkins with a stern test and a clear

Garnets Challenge
Booters Saturday
By JEFF LAUREN
The varsity soccer team is preparing for its home game opener
against Swarthmore tomorrow
afternoon, after dropping its first
game to Gettysburg.
When the Bluejays take the
field at 12:00 noon, they may be
without the services of co-captain Pablo Drobny, high scorer
the past two seasons, and Kit
Battenfield, the starting left wing
Coach Gary Barrette feels that
the uncertain availability of Battenfield and Drobny changes the
entire outlook of the game and
his strategy. He may shift Wes
Bachur from right wing, where
he has played for the last two
Years, to the inside of the offensive line since he is the only
experienced player left on the
line.
Working along with Bachur on
the line will be a group of speedy
and hustling sophomores. While
Coach Barrette will probably not
decide on his starting line-up
until Friday or Saturday, sophomores Art Guerin, Carl Ahrendt,
Lou Sardella and Ken Niman are
sure to see plenty of action on
the offensive squad.
The strategy calls for a fast
moving, hustling line that will
hopefully keep the pressure on
Swarthmore.
Hopkins w11 face a strong,
highly polished unit tomorrow
afternoon. Eleven lettermen, led

Complete Bachelor
Service

by co-captains Frank Briggs and
Mike Herbert, are on teh Swarthmore team, which carries only
seventeen men. But these seventeen are all highly, individually
skilled players, who rarely make
mistakes. There are a number
of foreign students on the squad,
with two of them the stars of
the club. Geoff Mwangulu from
Karonga, Malawi and Peter
Katzenstein from Hamburg, Germany are Swarthmore's prize
players.
For the Swarthmore game, a
modified zone defense will probably be used. An extra half-back
will most likely be used on defense line, leaving only four men
on the offensive line. The
Swarthmore offense boasts highly skilled dribblers and kickers,
so a man to man defense would
most likely prove unsuccessful.

Commission Reverses Key Decision
The possession of a master key
to campus buildings will no longer be considered a violation of
the Honor Code in accordance
with a recent commission decision; this reversed a previous
ruling which stated such possession to be a violation.
The immediate cause of the
original ruling was the theft of
tests by an undergraduate. The
result was severe controversy
and criticism from many facets
of the college community.
Re-examined Postion
John Sanborn, chairman of the
Honor Commission, remarked
"Pressure of the News-Letter
helped us to re-examine our position."
The original decision stated
that possession of said master
keys to Mergenthaler, Rowland,
Latrobe, Ames, Maryland or
Remsen Halls would be a violation of the Honor Code.
Holders of such keys were ad-

vised at the time to surrender
them to the proper authorities.
Chairman
stated
Sanborn
that while he "felt tradition was
being violated, the act would be
for the goad of the undergraduate body as a whole."
Nothing Violated
At that time the commission
felt that no constiutional provisions were being violated.
Sanborn stated that the commission soon realized "the constitution was grounded in tradition as well as reason."
Although the vote on the resolution was unanimous, the
members of the committee were
filled with doubt within a week.
With regard to this "paradox"
Sanborn stated, "We did it too
quickly, we didn't think enough."
In regard to the subsuquent
discovery that the act was indeed unconstitutional, he commented, "We hadn't read that
sentence of the constitution."

By last May the commission
realized the error of its ways.
Steps were taken to reverse the
ruling and Sanborn himself
spoke to several deans. This has
resulted in an agreement that
these gentlemen and not the
commission would have jurisdiction in this area.
Sanborn stated that with regard to future activities of the
commission, "this action will
cause the commission to be more
careful in the future."
Sanborn stated "that although
possession of a key is a potential academic advantage, it does
fall under the auspices of the
commission. The act must be
committed. We are not interested
in intent." It should be noted
that another such potential advantage would be in taking a
test outside the classroom.
The vote to reverse the original
unanimous decision was 19-1
with one absentee.

Speaker Sparseness
Reflecting upon the array of speakers scheduled
to appear at Hopkins this year, we find that a preponderance of scholarly figures will dominate the scene,
with remarkably few political and social critics on the
program.
The philosophy of science lecture series and the
inauguration of the symposium on literary structuralism
go far in fulfilling the University's responsibility to make
students aware of the variety of viewpoints existing elsewhere in the academic community. However, the University has a concurrent duty to stimulate interest in
the affairs and problems which characterize the real
world just beyond the cloistered halls of Homewood,
and in which students will soon have, if they do not
already, a more than academic involvement.
At present, Hopkins can look forward only to the
presentations of Secretary of Urban Affairs Robert
Weaver and Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield,
politicians who undoubtedly can do much to illuminate
domestic and international issues, but who, of themselves, are unlikely to evoke controversy on this campus.
This situation may be contrasted with the events of
two years ago, when PresideneJohnson twice descended
upon Hopkins, first during his campaign, and later in
the spring to make what has come to be known as his
"Baltimore speech".
That year also saw lectures by some of the foremost authorities on international affairs: Senators
Wayne Morse and William Fulbright, Ambassador Henry
Cabot Lodge, and then presidential advisor McGeorge
Bundy. In addition, Martin Luther King gave a moving
oration in Shrivec Hall, where Alabama's Governor
George Wallace had appeared the spring before.
In addition to the valuable insight into the issues
of Vietnam and civil rights rendered by each of these
speakers, their very presence wrought an impressive
change upon the usually sedate campus, culminating in
the demonstrations and counter-demonstrations when
Johnson and Bundy appeared.
Two years later, these issues are still very much
alive, and new ones have come along. Personnages such
as Secretary of Defense Robert MacNamara, U.N. Ambassador Arthur Goldberg, and Senator Robert Kennedy are among thsoe whose presence on campus would
generate immediate interest and controversy. Not to
limit the alternatives to the political realm, why not extend invitations to someone like Norman Mailer, or
Timothy Leary?
In its future planning, the Office of Special Events
would do well to keep in mind the importance of establishing a more balanced schedule of speakers, and the
benefits which students may derive in the form of increased personal activity in anticipation of or in the
wake of a confrontation with controversial public figures.

Round One
The Student Council is to he commended for its
forthrightness in a letter sent last week to several officials of the Administration.
Recognizing the dual concepts of freedom and responsibility as the foundation of Hopkins' philosophy
towards its students, Council president Reinseh went on
to write:
44
. • • a dichotomy has begun to develop
between the University philosophy and the reality of caniptis life ... the dichotomy lies in
w hat might be called the social realm; that is,
life at the University exclusive of studies.
And it is here that it is incumbent upon the
Student Council to point out as best it can a
trend away from the University's traditional
philosophy and toward a considerably more restrictive approach, which tends to limit the
freedom and responsibility of the student, and
places a greater burden upon the administration."
Among those examples cited by Reinsch to point
out this trend were the recent imposition of more rigid
regulations governing the freshman dormitories, and
the current rule prohibiting girls in the freshman dorms
at any time. Along with the Student Council, we urge
a reconsideration of these rules, and a general reevaluation of the entire dormitory set-up.
We hope to see initial talks taking place between
the Council and the Administration, with the possibility
of opening them to all students in the form of a panel
discussion or a forum at a later time.
We must point out that the academic freedom
which the letter applauds also appears to he facing this
name trend. The prime example here is the moving up
of the drop date. In both this instance and in the social
context above, the Administration seems to be forcing
die students to conform to the inadequacies of the University, rather than amelioratiing the inadequacies for
the benefit of the students.

Bureaucratic Tyranny
To the Editors,
Among the reasons university
education in Europe is so far superior to even "the best in
America" the local euphemism
for JHU) is that professors there
are not allowed to limit the educational opportunities of their
students by the petty and destructive use of bureaucratic tyranny, as was done at JHU in regard to the drop date.
Returning from a year's study
in Europe, I find it hardly conceivable that a professor should
voice the comments attributed
by the Newsletter (Oct. 7) to
Dean Swanson on the "abuse" of
the late drop date. Undoubtedly
I have been living in a youthful
honalee-world, for I would•have
thought that any dedicated professor would welcome any addi-

tional flexibility in the bureaucracy which would allow more
students to try his discipline.
The
American
educational
system is beset with enough obstacles to learning, without professors turning coal to the side
of educational restriction and ignorance.
Sincerely.
Michael Fischer, '67

Bookstore Discount
To the Editors,
Right from the start of this
semester the Student Council has
focused attention on different
aspects of the Hopkins Bookstore. However, in all this discussion, one essential fact seems
to have been neglected.
Faculty and Post doctoral students here at Hopkins do receive
a 10% discount on books and
supplies at the bookstore. Certainly, the purpose is to encourage these members of the community to purchase as many
books as possible in order to
pursue their various scholarly
interests. Such a discount then
lessens the financial strain on
these individuals and encourages
them to work and obtain ma-

terials through the campus bookstore. No one could argue that
this is not in the true spirit of
the university.
Why then are not students
granted such an incentive? Certainly the cost of books is high
and especially in the case of
students on partial scholarship
may be prohibitive. Which of us
has not at one time or another
hesitated from purchasing that
"recommended" book?
It is hard to imagine that the
Hopkins student is financially
more able to meet book costs
than faculty members and I
would suspect that the reverse
is true. Is it really necessary for
students to go to downtown
Washington, New York. and
other universities to find books
at a marked discount.
Hopefully the current expansion of the University bookstore
is only the first step toward more
substantial bookstore reform. A
major university like Hopkins
should certainly encourage its
students and faculty alike to buy
any and all books that will add
to their intelectual development.
James Jacobs,'69

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE OCTOBER 14, 1966

Harriers Edge Hounds; Gridders Brace For 'Fords
Balanced Performance After Tough Loss to Bears
Leads to One-Point Win
By TOM CROCK
With a tremendous comefrom -behind performance, the
varsity crosscountry team defeated Loyola 29-30 this week.
Loyola's fine sophomore strider, Tom Carter, took individual
honors, finishing about 300 yards
ahead of the rest of the field.
Second place also went to Loyola, but Hopkins' captain, Jack
Loomis gave the team its big
lift by finishing third, 60 yards
ahead of Loyola's third man.
At this point, after taking
three of the first four places,
Loyola's coach said that his
boys had the meet wrapped up.
Hopkins' coach George Brown
simply commented, "Wait and

and so on. Loyola took first
place, second, fourth, eleventh,
and twelfth for its 30 points.
Hopkins took third, fifth, sixth,
seventh, and eighth for 29. So
even though the last two Hopkins' runners figure in the scoring they had to finish ahead of
Loyola's final two runners to win
the meet.
This is the second straight
year that Hopkins has defeated
Loyola by one point in a crosscountry meet.
The Jays next meet is scheduled for tomorrow against Haverford and Drexel on the Homewood course at 2:00 P.M.

Hopkins' harriers Cliff Cyr,
Ed Minch, Larry Hoppwood, Bob
Gayle, Paul Carlson, and Jerry
Danoff were the next six runners to finish with Danoff far
ahead of the last two Loyola
men.
A meet like this shows the
value of having a well-balanced
team. Even though Loyola had
two fine runners that finished
well ahead of the Hopkins' pack,
the Jay's overall balance was
able to counter this advantage.
The score of a cross-country
meet is determined by the position of the first five finishers of
each team. One point is awarded
for first place, two for second,

With a mere eighteen men on
iihe roster, the freshman soccer
team opens its season this coining Wednesday, Oct. 19, at home
against Calvert Hall.
Even though Coach Charles
Mallonee started with twentysix men and lost his two top
prospects to injuries, he is still
optimistic for a good season.
His probable starters have plenty
of experience. He has an exceptionally good goalie, and he is
hoping to improve on last year's
2-1-2 record.
The loss of the two players on
whom Coach Mallonee based his
early plans was a harsh blow to
the potential of the beam. One
was Josh Geberer, an all-New
Jersey fullback, out with a severty sprained ankle, who hopefully
will return to the team later in
the season.
The second freshmen prospect
who was injured is Randy Miller,
a star halfback from West Hartford, Cann. He will be lost for
the entire season due to an injury.

Haverford tomorrow at 2:00 p.m.
in a contest which could, as it
did last year, prove to be the
turning point of the season.
Just as they did last year, the
Jay's take an 0-1-1 record and
a lot of uncertainties into the
game. They saw the pattern of the
rest of the campaign unfold last
season when they fell 36-16 to
Haverford. Following this trendsetter were four consecutive lopsided losses.

lettermen and a veteran backfield returning, should, despite,
two losses already, provide Hopkins with a stern test and a clear

Booters Saturday
By JEFF LAUREN
The varsity soccer team is preparing for its home game opener
against Swarthmore tomorrow
afternoon, after dropping its first
game to Gettysburg.
When the Bluejays take the
field at 12:00 noon, they may be
without the services of co-captain Pablo Drobny, high scorer
the past two seasons, and Kit
Battenfield, the starting left wing
Coach Gary Barrette feels that
the uncertain availability of Battenfield and Drobny changes the
entire outlook of the game and
his strategy. He may shift Wes
Bachur from right wing, where
he has played for the last two
Years, to the inside of the offensive line since he is the only
experienced player left on the
line.
Working along with Bachur on
the line will be a group of speedy
and hustling sophomores. While
Coach Barrette will probably not
decide on his starting line-up
until Friday or Saturday, sophomores Art Guerin, Carl Ahrendt,
Lou Sardella and Ken Niman are
sure to see plenty of action on
the offensive squad.
The strategy calls for a fast
moving, hustling line that will
hopefully keep the pressure on
Swarthmore.
Hopkins w11 face a strong,
highly polished unit tomorrow
afternoon. Eleven lettermen, led

Complete Bachelor
Service

by co-captains Frank Briggs and
Mike Herbert, are on teh Swarthmore team, which carries only
seventeen men. But these seventeen are all highly, individually
skilled players, who rarely make
mistakes. There are a number
of foreign students on the squad,
with two of them the stars of
the club. Geoff Mwangulu from
Karonga, Malawi and Peter
Katzenstein from Hamburg, Germany are Swarthmore's prize
players.
For the Swarthmore game, a
modified zone defense will probably be used. An extra half-back
will most likely be used on defense line, leaving only four men
on the offensive line. The
Swarthmore offense boasts highly skilled dribblers and kickers,
so a man to man defense would
most likely prove unsuccessful.
